title: Smart Pill Dispenser — STM32-Based Medication Management System
summary: A smart pill dispenser that helps patients take the correct medication at the right time, built on an STM32 microcontroller with sensors and motors that automatically dispense pills according to a timing schedule.
problem: Patients, especially elderly users, can miss or double-take medication doses when they rely on manual pill organisers or memory alone.
solution: The dispenser authenticates staff via RFID, schedules doses using an RTC, and uses a servo-driven mechanism plus sensors to release and verify the correct medication at each scheduled time.
targetUsers: Elderly patients on multiple medications and caregivers who need a reliable way to track adherence.
impact: Improved dosing reliability during prototype tests and gave caregivers clearer visibility into whether doses were dispensed and retrieved on time.
tech: STM32, Embedded C++, RFID, RTC, IR Sensor, PIR Sensor, Servo Motor, OLED Display, Keypad
responsibilities: Developed the C++ firmware for the STM32, integrating sensors, motors, and system control logic.
Implemented RFID access control, RTC-based scheduling, IR/PIR detection, and servo actuation modules.
Configured STM32 peripherals, sensor inputs, interrupts, and timing functions.
Performed end-to-end troubleshooting of sensor readings, motor movement, timing accuracy, and firmware behaviour.
Collaborated with teammates to validate system operation across hardware and firmware components.
features: RFID authentication for secure staff access.
IR and motion sensors to verify pill release and detect user presence.
OLED display with keypad for configuration and status.
learnings: Building an embedded system from concept to working prototype.
Writing embedded C++ for STM32 and integrating multiple sensors and actuators.
Configuring microcontroller peripherals and interrupts for real-time behaviour.
Debugging timing faults, signal noise, and mechanical alignment issues.
Testing and validating a complete embedded hardware–software system.
heroAlt: Smart pill dispenser prototype with STM32 and pill slots

title: Supermarket Self-Checkout System — IoT Kiosk + Web Platform
summary: A Raspberry Pi–powered self-checkout kiosk paired with a full web app for cart management and payment.
tech: Python Backend, SQL / MariaDB, Raspberry Pi, Docker, REST APIs, Web Frontend
heroAlt: Supermarket self-checkout kiosk with keypad and LCD
problem: Conventional manned checkout counters create queues and require more staff during peak hours.
solution: Built a kiosk that lets customers scan items, manage their cart locally, then sync to a web backend for payment and receipt.
responsibilities: Maintained the Dockerised backend and database.
Monitored Raspberry Pi kiosk health and performed on-site troubleshooting.
Coordinated integration testing between kiosk and web interfaces.
features: Item scanning and cart management on the kiosk.
Persistent cart synced to a web application.
Containerised backend for easy deployment and rollback.
